ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Random Initialisation
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin Actually, poking around I haven t seen anything yet on folks trying dynamic population sizes. It might be a feasible approach if you re seemingly stuck

Colin

Actually, poking around I haven't seen anything yet on folks trying =
dynamic
population sizes. It might be a feasible approach if you're seeming=
ly stuck
and not increasing the best fitness for a while. Probably would be=
 best
implemented with your phased pruning as a precursor to population gro=
wth to
speed things up as best you can.

This is giving me ideas to try out=
 for thesis proposals. Now I just have to
figure out MPI and get a cluster =
going at work. I've got 8 core i7 boxes
sitting idle nights and weekends, d=
efinitely need to put those to use.

If anyone has any thoughts on this, I'=
m all ears. I'm particularly
interested in the fractured domain problem, al=
though I probably need to get
a handle on leaky integrators in my implement=
ation first.


-Drew

On Fri, Mar 25, 2011 at 12:51 PM, Drew Kirkpatrick <
=
drew.kirkpatrick@...> wrote:

> Colin,
>
> Just curious as I've been =
thinking about this a bit lately (I'm new to NEAT
> stuff), as it seems tha=
t the micro mutations you talk about, if
> I'm interpreting papers right, i=
s one of the reasons standard NEAT doesn't
> handle fractured domain proble=
ms well. As you say, it can't "get there from
> here". It can't build enoug=
h structure and optimize it's performance to find
> a better solution befor=
e that species dies out.
>
> Is this the problem you're looking to address =
here? Or just a method of
> escaping a local maxima in fitness by allowing =
more radical
> adjustments/growth to network topologies in general?
>
> One=
 thing I was wondering about, and I haven't poked around to see if
> anyone=
 has done some research into, is fiddling with the species die-off
> parame=
ter. I was thinking it might be worth trying (if someone hasn't done
> it y=
et), is to remove the species die off if-hasn't-improved-in X
> generations=
 bit if no species fitness has improved in some specified amount
> of gener=
ations.
>
> I think if you've sat with the same "champion" for a large numb=
er of
> generations, it could be worthwhile to do something radical, like g=
reatly
> increase mutations, stop killing off sub-performing species, great=
ly
> increase the topology, or even (if you have a cluster, or a lot of tim=
e),
> stop restricting the population size (that could get ugly quick). Let=
 the
> population grow on it's own for X generations, to help diversify thi=
ngs a
> bit. After X generations of population explosion, go back to a set
=
> population size by killing off the under performing species.
>
> If figur=
e that if you're seemingly stuck in what appears to be a local
> maxima in =
the solution space, why not slow things down a bit with a huge
> population=
, larger mutations, to diversify the search a bit?
>
> I'm sure someone has=
 toyed with this at some point. I can always use
> another couple hundred o=
f pages of papers/dissertations to add to my
> "to-be-read" pile going into=
 my thesis :)
>
> Sorry if I'm rambling, pre-coffee here.
>
>
> -Drew
>
>
>=
 On Thu, Mar 24, 2011 at 11:43 PM, Colin Green <colin.green1@...>wrot=
e:
>
>>
>>
>> This is an idea that follows from the discussion on networks =
with
>> arbitrary complexity possibly being useful as starting points for
>=
> biological brains.
>>
>> Very simply I'm considering experimenting with r=
andom initial
>> populations of varying sizes & complexities (and perhaps s=
chemes for
>> generating random connections/nodes) and then running NEAT in=
 pruning
>> mode first before complexifying. The pruning potentially gets y=
ou back
>> to a population of low complexity networks that have more divers=
ity
>> than we normally start with. The motivation is that this might help =
in
>> the "you can't get there from here" problem of being stuck in some
>>=
 sub-space of the fitness landscape. Starting with no nodes or even no
>> c=
onnections puts the whole population in one part of the sub-space
>> from w=
hich it might struggle to escape - this is especially true if
>> you factor=
 neywork size into the fitness function which is an idea
>> I've bounced ar=
ound before.
>>
>> Further to this I'm also thinking about network mutation=
s that do more
>> than the current 'micro' mutations we all tend to use (ad=
d/delete
>> connection or weight change). We sort of do something like this=

>> already in that a weight change mutation can be for a single
>> connect=
ion or applied to all or some proportion of connections. In
>> addition I p=
ropose that connection addition/deletion mutations that
>> perform multiple=
 mutations as one operation might have beneficial
>> effects over and above=
 the normal approach of aggregating positive
>> mutations over time and thr=
ough crossover. Again the motivation is in
>> helping NEAT to make slightly=
 bolder jumps into new regions of the
>> fitness space (but not too bold).
=
>>
>> One can also invisage having a very large number of new connections a=
s
>> part of a single mutation, but that have very low connection weights
>=
> such that they are almost functionally redundant (but not entirely).
>> T=
he beneficial connections may 'grow' in strength and the useless ones
>> wo=
uld get eliminated during pruning.
>>
>> Colin
>>  
>>
>
>

<div>Colin</div><div><br></div>Actually, poking around I haven't seen a=
nything yet on folks trying dynamic population sizes. It might be a=A0feasi=
ble=A0approach if you're seemingly stuck and not increasing the best fi=
tness for a while. Probably would be best implemented with your phased prun=
ing as a precursor to population growth to speed things up as best you can.=
=A0<div>

<br></div><div>This is giving me ideas to try out for thesis prop=
osals. Now I just have to figure out MPI and get a cluster going at work. I=
've got 8 core i7 boxes sitting idle nights and weekends, definitely ne=
ed to put those to use.=A0</div>

<div><br></div><div>If anyone has any tho=
ughts on this, I'm all ears. I'm particularly interested in the fra=
ctured domain problem, although I probably need to get a handle on leaky in=
tegrators in my implementation first.</div>

<div><br></div><div><br></div>=

 been thinking about this a bit lately (I'm new to NEAT stuff), as it s=
eems that the micro mutations you talk about, if I'm=A0interpreting=A0p=
apers right, is one of the reasons standard NEAT doesn't handle fractur=
ed domain problems well. As you say, it can't "get there from here=
". It can't build enough structure and optimize it's performan=
ce to find a better solution before that species dies out.=A0</div>


<div>=
<br></div><div>Is this the problem you're looking to address here? Or j=
ust a method of escaping a local maxima in fitness by allowing more radical=
 adjustments/growth to network topologies in general?</div><div><br>


</di=
v><div>One thing I was wondering about, and I haven't poked around to s=
ee if anyone has done some research into, is fiddling with the species die-=
off parameter. I was thinking it might be worth trying (if someone hasn&#39=
;t done it yet), is to remove the species die off if-hasn't-improved-in=
 X generations bit if no species fitness has improved in some specified amo=
unt of generations.=A0</div>


<div><br></div><div>I think if you've sa=
t with the same "champion" for a large number of generations, it =
could be worthwhile to do something radical, like greatly increase mutation=
s, stop killing off sub-performing species, greatly increase the topology, =
or even (if you have a cluster, or a lot of time), stop restricting the pop=
ulation size (that could get ugly quick). Let the population grow on it&#39=
;s own for X generations, to help diversify things a bit. After X generatio=
ns of population explosion, go back to a set population size by killing off=
 the under performing species.=A0</div>


<div><br></div><div>If figure tha=
t if you're seemingly stuck in what appears to be a local maxima in the=
 solution space, why not slow things down a bit with a huge population, lar=
ger mutations, to diversify the search a bit?=A0</div>

orry if I'm rambling, pre-coffee here.</div><div><br></div><div><br></d=

quote">On Thu, Mar 24, 2011 at 11:43 PM, Colin Green <span dir=3D"ltr"><=
<a href=3D"mailto:colin.green1@..." target=3D"_blank">colin.green1@gm=
ail.com</a>></span> wrote:<br>


<blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=
=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1ex">







=






<div style=3D"background-color:#fff">
<span>=A0</span>


<div>
  <div=
>


    <div>
      
      
      <p>This is an idea that follows from the =
discussion on networks with<br>
arbitrary complexity possibly being useful =
as starting points for<br>
biological brains.<br>
<br>
Very simply I'm =
considering experimenting with random initial<br>
populations of varying si=
zes & complexities (and perhaps schemes for<br>
generating random conne=
ctions/nodes) and then running NEAT in pruning<br>
mode first before comple=
xifying. The pruning potentially gets you back<br>
to a population of low c=
omplexity networks that have more diversity<br>
than we normally start with=
. The motivation is that this might help in<br>
the "you can't get=
 there from here" problem of being stuck in some<br>
sub-space of the =
fitness landscape. Starting with no nodes or even no<br>
connections puts t=
he whole population in one part of the sub-space<br>
from which it might st=
ruggle to escape - this is especially true if<br>
you factor neywork size i=
nto the fitness function which is an idea<br>
I've bounced around befor=
e.<br>
<br>
Further to this I'm also thinking about network mutations t=
hat do more<br>
than the current 'micro' mutations we all tend to u=
se (add/delete<br>
connection or weight change). We sort of do something li=
ke this<br>
already in that a weight change mutation can be for a single<br=
>
connection or applied to all or some proportion of connections. In<br>
ad=
dition I propose that connection addition/deletion mutations that<br>
perfo=
rm multiple mutations as one operation might have beneficial<br>
effects ov=
er and above the normal approach of aggregating positive<br>
mutations over=
 time and through crossover. Again the motivation is in<br>
helping NEAT to=
 make slightly bolder jumps into new regions of the<br>
fitness space (but =
not too bold).<br>
<br>
One can also invisage having a very large number of=
 new connections as<br>
part of a single mutation, but that have very low c=
onnection weights<br>
such that they are almost functionally redundant (but=
 not entirely).<br>
The beneficial connections may 'grow' in streng=
th and the useless ones<br>
would get eliminated during pruning.<br>
<br>
C=
olin<br>
</p>

    </div>
     

    
    <div style=3D"color:#fff;min-heig=
ht:0"></div>


</div>



  






</blockquote></div><br></div></div></div>=

</blockquote></div><br></div>
